plist.p: Okay. Good morning, everybody. And a particular welcome to those that have trekked all the way up to rural Norwest. And welcome our home. And for those that are joining us online, thank you for joining us.

I might say that we had a little trouble with a couple of calls with – during question time for those that are online. And it really was those that were using headsets or using mobile phones, we really had a little trouble breaking up. Those that used landlines, we had no trouble at all. So in thinking about how you might make your question for those online, just consider if you've got a landline that you can use it would make the experience and our ability to understand your question a lot easier.

Okay. The financial year 2011, so again, particularly in the second half, we had macroeconomic conditions, particularly around consumer sentiment that were very challenging, and Mother Nature also put a few challenges in their way in both Australia and New Zealand. But despite that, we managed to have a very positive overall result of plus 5.1% in net profit after tax, or 6.5% when you exclude those direct noninsured costs that we've identified in relation to the natural disasters in Australia and New Zealand.

With a year in which we were able to identify that we increased market share in just about all of our businesses, and where we couldn't measure the entire business, particularly in segments where we did have measurement, and we continued in of all our businesses to invest significantly in reducing prices for customers. And of course, that was assisted somewhat, particularly with imported products, with the strong Australian dollar that generally brought retail prices down. We also continued to focus on making sure that we were listening to our customers, so range, formats, the all-important prices and, of course, multi-channel has been a very important part of our growth in the past year and will be an exceedingly important part of our growth going forward.

We, once again, finished the year with a very strong balance sheet, higher cash flows. And during the year, we're able to give our shareholders back $700 million through a buyback. And Tom will take us through some of the more finer details of that a little bit later. And we were able to continue to finance growth. So we certainly put a greater level of effort into our existing businesses with 180 gross new stores and 233 refurbs across our group. But more importantly, we also prepared for the opening of our new business in Home Improvement.

And I think when you look over the last 10 years, what has been very obvious has been our ability in both the high and the low times to continue to deliver both the superior value to our customers, but also positive profit and returns to our shareholders through all the economic cycles.

To the actual numbers. Most of you have had the chance to read through these, having an earlier looks. The sales, of course, up 4.7, EBITDA, up 6.6, EBIT up 6.3 and NPAT, as I mentioned before, up 5.1 and EPS up 6.5 and the dividends with the – pardon me, the dividend being confirmed this morning by the board, up 6.1 per share. Our ROFE was slightly down, however. Tom will point out that we've invested significantly in property, particularly in the Home Improvement area over the last year. And, of course, Cellarmasters we bought in May, and didn't have the benefit of the full 12 months of trade in that business.

So over to the highlights. Price leadership has been the hallmark of Woolworths and it continues to be, whether it's that petrol pricing promise that says we're going to match the lowest in the market area and we're going to give you $0.04. Or whether that Dan Murphy promise that says you're not going to find it cheaper anywhere else, or Dick Smith doing deals or the Dare to Compare wall or the trolley as you come through the front door of BIG W pointing out our price advantage over others.

Once again in our supermarkets, we continue the tradition of price leadership. We've had the biggest selling value brand in the market, and it's been with us since 1983, and Homebrand continues to grow. In January 2010, we led the market. We led the market by dropping 5,000 prices. It was followed some months later by others, and in February, we went back with our further confirmation to our customers that we're going to be committing to our promise to make sure that they have the value basket of the – with price knockdown.

In fresh food we outgrew, by the market data we've just received in the last week, all other competitors for the year and for the quarter. And there is no doubt that our focus on the fresh food has been unyielding. So whether it's the fixed price guarantee on those key commodity items that we've held are first in the marketplace, our fresh food guarantee that if you're not comfortable with what you bought bring it back, we'll give your money back or the great Macro Wholefood Market range.

More importantly, I think with the 2015 new format in supermarkets, what we've seen is the marked fresh food participation in those stores over and above our – the rest of our fleet. So we're very, very happy with fresh food.

Talking about new formats, we'll have over half either in the 2015 or the 2010, and we've got another 21 stores coming up in the 2015 format during the year. And both our sales results, particularly in Fresh but also the focus groups that we've held around 2015, have been overwhelmingly positive from our customers.

Multi-channel has been a tremendous area of growth for us; sales up 63%. We launched Dan Murphy online during the year and it's worked particularly well. New BIG W opened just before the start of the financial year and it's continued to grow. Dick Smith is growing week-on-week, particularly with 'click and collect', and some of the – their Daily Deals, et cetera. And we believe that this now has been one of the, if not the most, visited site for electronics in the Australasian marketplace. And last week we had a record sales for Dick Smith online. I think more importantly, in terms of food, we now cover 85% of the Australian population with plans to take that number higher. And New Zealand online business also is growing in line with the Australian business. Pardon me.

This is not to do with last year, but this is a very exciting thing that if you haven't seen in the media or haven't participated in, I – if you've got an iPhone or an iPad, I suggest you do. This has become the number one app with a bullet, and we've had 400,000 people download this app already in the first couple of days. And we're seeing people walking around the store doing their shopping using this app. So if you haven't had a look at it, I suggest you do. It's pretty exciting.
Excuse me. I'm just battling a man cold at the moment. I call it flu, but the ladies on the team call it man cold.

Our Liquor business approached nearly $6 billion. And what's been really important in our Liquor business was an outstanding market share growth well ahead of any other competitor and well ahead of the marketplace in the last year. The photograph that you have there is our newest format store in Victoria and it's doing really well. Private label, big part of our Dan Murphy and Liquor business overall, and there were an additional 70 new lines for the year introduced.

One of the exciting things, of course, has been our vertical and horizontal integration into new channels and new production capabilities with the acquisition of Cellarmasters. And to date, Greg and his team have delivered over and above our expectations in both revenue and EBIT. So we're thinking that there are many, many opportunities going forward, and perhaps a little later in the year Greg, through Grant, will be able to share some of our plans going forward.

Countdown, largest and most trusted super brand – supermarket brand in New Zealand, that's largest brand by sales now in New Zealand. And last night, it actually was also given the gong for the best marketing by a company in New Zealand the past year, which was fantastic; market share growth on all the metrics. We've got 88% of the fleet now trading as Countdown, but we've still got lots of upside because 62% of the fleet are actually new, either 2010 or 2015 format. So they get to be refurbished across.

Could I say here, both in regard to New Zealand and also to our Australian teams in the case of both of the – or the number of natural disasters, what a wonderful and self-sacrificing efforts that we saw across our business where people put their own personal needs aside to come in to make sure that we looked after our customers in both countries. And it was a very humbling event to watch the efforts that they put in over that time.

BIG W, still the real leader in price. So whether it's our dare to compare, or you prove to yourself by having a look at the prices that we have – this is our competition. We continue to have price leadership. We're continuing to invest in new stores and refurbs and quality branded products such as the Mambo and the new innovative brands like Morrissey. And our business with the optical is also growing quite strongly. So we're very excited about the future here. We just need the Aussie dollar and deflation to move in the right direction.

Dick Smith, a tale of two cities. We're very comfortable that, particularly the new format stores are doing well in sales. We've done a really good job in the past year in a highly deflationary area in reducing our cost of doing business, so well done to Deborah and the team. We still have got quite a way to go to get the right gross margin, which has been challenging globally in that. So we will continue to focus on making sure that we have a profitable business there.

In laptops and table top computers and also tablet computers, we've had tremendous growth over last year and particularly with the additional tables that were put into Dick Smith. That particular category has had very, very strong growth.

Our customer engagement program continues to go from strength-to-strength. We've got 8.4 million members across Australia and New Zealand. A really great innovation in the last quarter was the ability for people to convert their points, their Qantas Frequent Flyer points, to gift cards on a regional basis. So for those that are either not interested in flights or have other means of getting flights, this is a wonderful alternative for them, and we already have some significant shift across for people that wish to do exactly that.

Our credit cards and debit cards continue to perform well. So the Qantas card that was launched last November took the lion's share of new credit cards that were adopted by Australians in the time since it was launched. The debit cards have been way above our expectations, and we just see more and more growth in this particular area in financial services.

Home improvement. Our first store is scheduled to open in Melbourne in the next little while. And those that have had the opportunity internally to visit the store have seen what we said in saying that this is going to be a different offer to perhaps what they might have seen elsewhere. And we see this as a wonderful opportunity.

What we have taken the opportunity to do today is to – just to look at the market. This is a new business that we're starting up, and it has costs of starting up. So it's got new distribution centers. It's got a new central team. It's got pre-opening costs. It's got training costs. It's got stock that we've got to put in. It's got launch marketing. And most stores take two to three years to mature in profitability. So we will be taking to the bottom line up to $100 million next year, or this year that we're in, for startup costs.

The alternative, of course, is buying a business where you put a good goal in the balance sheet and you don't have the opportunity to actually put that against your profit. And, of course, the $100 million, up to a $100 million, will be available to put against profits in a future date. So it's not all doom and gloom.

I think the important thing to note is that we've been through this before. We opened one BIG W store back in, I think, 1976 when there were a hundred and something Kmarts and Targets or whatever, and people said we were crazy. We bought a little business to be the first of our non-supermarket Liquor businesses in Dan Murphy, and now we've got market leadership. We opened our first petrol station, and people said you're crazy taking on the big guys, but we now have market leadership in petrol.

So we've been through it, we're comfortable that we know what we have to do. We know what it's going to cost because we've had experience in the past in building businesses. But it's really important – when we looked at the financial community and looked at their forward estimates, there were only a couple that actually had any dollars against it.

So it's really important for us to that we keep transparency with the marketplace to let people know that starting new businesses cost money, and we're willing to invest this. The alternative, if it was available, was to buy one. And you'd spend a lot more on goodwill than that to actually buy a new business. This is a fantastic opportunity for us and, of course, that hundred will very much depend on the speed at which we roll these out. Now we estimate that we'll be at breakeven around about three – three to four years, but once again that will depend on how fast we go.

We will most likely have up to 19 stores opened in the first 18 months, 12 months to 18 months, so we're going to go pretty hard. So we're going open in Victoria. We've got a number in Queensland, and we'll be back to Victoria, et cetera. But we're very confident this is a great growth opportunity for the future for us.

In supply chain innovation, we continue to invest in our supply chain, whether it's the Hoppers Crossing DC for Home Improvement or the Hawkstone Park campus for BIG W, Dick Smith and Home Improvement or the new National Distribution Centre that we opened in New Zealand. The refurb and refit of our two national DCs and automated DCs in Melbourne and Sydney that have been completed that give us improved efficiency in cost, the Next Generation of replenishment, which is the replacement in the longer term for AutostockR and Stocksmart, or the meat plant. We will continue to invest in delivering greater efficiencies for our business going forward.

We made a promise to ourselves and the market sometime back that we would put ourselves at the front of all global retailers by having a 40% reduction in our carbon footprint on a like-for-like basis by 2015, and we will achieve that. Our present trend rate says that we will achieve it. So initiatives last year, some 37; one of them was a New Green store in Inverell that just completed the first year of trade for BIG W and it had, for a similar store in the same climate, a 30% plus reduction in energy consumption. We predict $120 million worth of savings that will come from these initiatives and nearly a billion tons worth of carbon equivalents will be taken out of the atmosphere as a result of our activities.

In corporate responsibility, we continue to show leadership there through our Ethical and Palm Oil Sourcing Policies and our Sustainable Seafood Policy. We continue to invest in the community, where it's appropriate. We launched our Reconciliation Action Plan in the past year. For instance, we've doubled the number of our indigenous teammates in real sustainable jobs. And once again we had another great outcome in terms of our safety, and I think we now, in terms of our metrics, are at the leading edge of similar businesses globally.

We remain committed to agriculture, so we are proud partners of Australian and New Zealand farmers. In Australia, we have 100% of our fresh of meat sourced from Australia and 97% of our fresh produce. And since 2007 we had a lot of the young farmers that have joined us here for a program that we've initiated. And in addition to that, on their farms, not their particular farms, but on many farms across the country, we've invested in Landcare initiatives to the tune of nearly $7 million. And we continue to sponsor things like the Royal Agricultural Show that are very important to the agricultural sector.

So to some of the numbers and the longer term trends. Our profit after tax 5.1, or 6.4 after excluding the natural disaster costs. EBIT up 6.3, you can see it was slightly higher than that excluding the natural disaster costs. Once again a strong performance by the Australian Food and Liquor group. CODB, no deflate other than petrol where we had deflation across our businesses to maintain an under 20% CODB. I think it was a terrific effort by our people considering that we had things like the electricity going up double-digit in terms of cost per megawatt, and we had obviously a 3% plus underlying inflationary labor cost each week. This was a great outcome.

Our gross profit, due to all the things that we've talked about in the past around direct store reduction, global sourcing, shrinkage, et cetera, private label, has seen a slight tick up in our gross margin and we've been able to do that across our business as well as still investing substantially in reduced prices. Our dividends per share, after the affirmation of the $0.65 dividend this morning for 2011, means that we've got $1.22 for our shareholders for the full year, up 6%.
Now I'd like to hand it over to Grant who will take us through some of the individual businesses and make some comments about those. Thanks, Grant.
Thanks, Michael. Good morning, everyone.

As Michael said, I'm going to just make some comments on each of the businesses individually with supermarkets being the first Australian supermarkets. It was a solid year with sales growth in the order of 4% with an improving comp sales position in the second half. And this was despite deflationary pressures in the order of about 3.6 for the second half. So we had good comp sales, improving comp sales, but also the deflation that we'd seen earlier in the year was still present in the second half and despite that, good top line growth.

The deflation means that you've got to get more customers into your store and sell more units in order to make positive territory in relation to sales. And I'm pleased to say in relation to the supermarkets, that's what happened. Significant growth in customers and units that we moved through the business, resulting in EBIT growth for the food, liquor and petrol business just a little shy of 8% growth, which is a strong result.

The hero in relation to this top line was fresh foods. Double digit growth in deli, in produce and in in-store bakery, and very strong numbers also in our meat division, as well. So really all the members of the fresh food club within our stores had a very good year, very positive year in terms of top-line sales growth. That resulted, as Mike has touched on already, in pleasing market share improvements in the Fresh areas, but also Liquor and also our Packaged Goods.

Price was a battleground during the course of the year, and Mike pointed to the knockdown glove. And the knockdown glove is the signal to our customers that we've got a contract with them, and that contract says that you'll get the best value in the marketplace when you shop with Woolworths, and we've maintained that during the year with the investment that we've made in pricing.

Multi-channel and online is an increasingly important part of our business, and our online Food business grew by 78% last year. So a strong result, and we see strong growth in that area going forward.

Space growth also remained in place for us. 21 new stores for the year was a good result by the property team in a depressed development market, with 21 stores and another good bunch of stores lined up for the year ahead. So space growth remained important for our ambitions, both this year and going forward for the Australian supermarket division.

The return on funds employed is something that we watch carefully in all of our divisions, but we're pretty proud of the one in supermarkets. And whilst it dipped slightly to be around 75%, if you back out the Cellarmasters acquisition at the end of the year, as Mike said, and also you back out the additional stock through goods that we're bringing in from our global sourcing office in China, we're in excess of 80% for our ROFE.

So a very strong business, historically strong business that continues to deliver with 80% return on the funds employed towards that business. So momentum is in the supermarket business that remains and we're confident about how we'll move forward.

Private Label was the other one I wanted to mention. In Private Label we added another 600 products this year to the Private Label stable. The one that's growing fastest is our Macro brand, which is our good for you brand. Great customer acceptance for that brand, and that's encouraging us to invest further in that item or that range within our stores.

Liquor. My description of Liquor is an outstanding year. And it's outstanding on all the measures we find important. It grew market share. And Dan Murphy's, as Mike alluded to early, was the hero of the Liquor area. But all major categories performed well in our Liquor business. So major categories for us are beer, wine and spirits. All of them were in positive territory despite consumption coming off over the course of the year. So consumption was a headwind, but we delivered positive sales results in the Liquor business.

Spirits was the standout. Our Spirits business grew by circa 12% over the course of the year. All in positive territory, courtesy of that was the market share growth that both Mike and I have alluded to.

Key drivers. Again, I'd point to space first of all. We rolled out 19 Dan Murphy's stores and 26 BWS stores to add to the fleet of Liquor businesses that we have around the country. But also important for us was our private label investment. We have a share, as you know, in the Gage Roads Brewery in WA, and that was courtesy of that investment that we launched four – three of our new brands this year, three new beer brands and also a cider brand.

The Cider category is on fire. It's the most significant growth in the liquor area at the moment. And we bought out our private label, I think importantly, at the beginning of the cycle. And we're getting good growth from that moving forward.

But it's the investment that we've made in both Cellarmasters, and it's the investment that we've made in Dan Murphy's online, which came online this year, that provides a pointer to some of the growth for next year.

The integration of the Cellarmasters business is ahead of schedule. The synergies that we're driving into that business are also ahead of target. So good news indeed from the investment that we were pretty confident about, but good to be on this side of it and see the real value that we predicted in that business.

Petrol, very pleasing result, despite the fact that volumes were flat. I'd like to point to the customer count increase of almost 4% for this business. We make a price promise to our customers in respect to Petrol, and they support that promise with their custom. 4% more customers this year. Flat market, but good growth from a dollar sales and a profitability point of view.

James and his team had particular focus this year on the shop on the four court (26:48), what we call the merchandise area of this business. And 10.7% growth was the reward for James and his team for the efforts that they put in to a pretty aggressive expansion of the offer in our four court stores for our Petrol business.

New Zealand supermarkets survived everything that Mother Nature threw at them and more. A really good year for the New Zealand team. Dave's here with us today, and we're in awe of what he and his team have done in battling those particular challenges and delivering a great result.

Michael said something in his speech and I want to repeat it because it's something we're pretty proud of. And that is that Countdown is the largest brand by turnover in New Zealand now. That's a long way from where it was when we acquired this business some years ago and is testament to the quality of the team that Dave leads in New Zealand.

We've got strong growth in key categories of perishables, it was up 6.5%. Produce up 6%, liquor up almost 8% in the New Zealand market, were really good figures courtesy of the aggressive approach that Dave and his team took into the marketplace.

Online has been established in the New Zealand market for some time, but it continued to grow and grew by some 24%. Online in New Zealand is, I think, about 1.7% in that order of our sales and growing. And indeed we're picking up in the final stages of taking the New Zealand platform and putting it into our business here in Australia, only month or two away from launching our new platform for our Food business here in Australia, courtesy of the New Zealand team.

Profit was, as shown, 5.1%, but if you back out the natural disaster costs, the EBIT growth was in the order of 9.5%, so a fantastic result from – in terms of profit. We're also trading here at the moment with one hand behind our back, maybe that's a bit of an exaggeration, but we've still got three stores closed in the Christchurch area; two of them are expected to be long-term, one of them hopefully back online in September though. Yep.

So three stores have been closed since the second of the earthquakes that we had in New Zealand, but as you can see on the chart a strengthening position in the second half and that's continued into this trading year.
BIG W is a business that we're pretty proud of, very solid business that has got a fantastic position in terms of price and value and a business that we are confident about building going forward.

It's had its challenges this year in relation to a number of its categories, particularly Home Entertainment and Apparel, suffering deflation – deflationary pressures. But really pleasing to see that in the second half, sales grew by a positive 2% and our profit in the second half grew over 5.5%, so good momentum in the second half. And when you look at the deflation, which across categories ranged from 6% to 9%, to get a positive sales result is a testament again to the team. More customers, a lot more units have to be put through our registers in order to get the sort of sales increase that we're talking about here.

Margin also was healthy, and a lot of that is being driven by increasing our reliance on global sourcing. We're getting more product out of China and Bangladesh and other sorts of areas supporting our apparel range improvements and the like. So that's been important, and that's important for mix.
But still with a large focus on brands. I think brands constitute about 70%, still, of our sales in BIG W, but we're doing that cleverly with the private label that we're investing in.

Costs were well controlled despite the fact we were put through a lot more customers and that we put through a lot more units. We didn't get the top line reward for it because of deflation. So I think Julie and her team have contained costs there pretty well given the volume that's moved through the stores.

Inventory is something we look at, obviously, very carefully in the BIG W business. The inventory at the end of this financial year was less than the inventory at the end of the previous financial year despite the fact that we added enough for our new stores. So with less inventory we're trading for more stores. So a good position to be in both in terms of sell through of the seasonal stock and management of closing stock by Julie and her team.

Consumer Electronics, positive story in as much as the new format stores are trading really well. And if we look at those in isolation, as you can see on the chart, some 7% increase in sales on the previous year courtesy of the new format stores. We're not where we want that – it's not where we want it to be yet because it's not driving the profitability yet that we want out of this business. So there's still much work to do here. But a couple of other things are appointed to the future for this business, and one is the increasing penetration of online. This is probably one of our most true multi-channel businesses that we have at this point in time. Our growth on online for Dick Smith grew about 76% last year, and interestingly, 25% of those purchases were 'click and collect'. In other words, they were purchased online and collected in the store.

So it's a highly featured Web site. It's a much visited Web site, to Mike's earlier comment, and it's trading pretty well at the moment. Particular categories that are trading strongly are around the notebooks, computer area and also around the connectivity – what we call the connectivity area in the Dick Smith business.

In respect to the New Zealand version of Dick Smith, it's a small business. It's suffered from the natural disasters. It's also suffering from deflation in many of its categories. The deflationary figure that we are quoting in relation to Dick Smith generally is 14% across its category, so there's significant deflation in that business.

We've got three stores still closed, just to update you on the Consumer Electronic business in New Zealand. Three stores still closed around the Christchurch area for Dick Smith. So hoping to get those back online in the near future, but I think a couple of them are in the same boat as the Countdown stores that I alluded to earlier.

Our little business in Croma is – in India rather, the Croma business, has been ticking away quietly in the background. Its profitability this year is pleasing around $4.3 million – $4.8 million; I beg your pardon, as opposed to $1.3 million the previous year. So it's got 62 stores, more stores being added on a regular basis, and through both the Hong Kong buying office and the skills of the buying team that we've got in India delivering more margins to that business and creating a greater wholesale margin for us, which is the area of the business that we operate in and that's where the increased bottom line is coming from.

Hotels is the last one I want to comment on. And the heading says resilient performance by the Hotel group. That's the best description I can come up with. It's a very solid result for Hotels, gaining 3.1% in a pretty challenging consumer environment, and profit up 4% to $184 million, so strong results.

The standout category was Food. Food is really important to this business, as we've said before, because the sorts of hotels that we promote are family hotels where there's affordable entertainment, affordable meals. And to see the Meals category or the Food category jump to the extent that it has and the growth momentum that it has is particularly pleasing for us because it endorses the strategy we have for Hotels and the sorts of clients that we want to attract to those.

Two more hotels carefully selected and added to the portfolio this year. The Dog & Parrot being one of them and the Robina in Queensland, just near the Robina Shopping Center, great hotel for us. Opportunity for a Danks to go on site, so good growth there, 282 hotels now in total.
So that's just a little bit of information on each of the trading divisions that I wanted to share with you. Tom's now going to go through the financials for you. Thanks, Tom.
Thanks, Grant, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll just take you through some of the elements of the cash flow and the balance sheet.

In relation to cash flow, we had a pretty good cash flow for the year. We had generated $2.9 billion in cash, which was up 8.7%. So that gave us a pretty good platform to do a fair amount of investment in our business.

So I'll just flip over to the next slide. I've just analyze the cash flow slightly differently. So you can see the cash of our after normal CapEx and dividends is about $600 million, which was up nicely from last year at 31%. So then we bought some businesses about $400-odd million. The largest in there of course is Cellarmasters at $340-odd million and the rest was sort of miscellaneous, hotels, home improvement businesses, et cetera.

We spent about $600 million net on continuing to develop our property pipeline. In a market where the development sector is still particularly weak, it's really important Woolworths continue to underpin its new store growth pipelines. So this isn't not – necessarily next year's stores, it's years in – stores in years three, four and five, but we were very encouraged by a pretty successful sales program during the year.

We also undertook a share buyback of just under $740 million. We funded that with primarily increasing borrowings, which I'll touch on in a moment. And after all that activity, our fixed charge cover remained at three and our interest service cover was 12.5. So it was a – we really maintained a strong balance sheet. We had some excess capacity there and we've returned money to shareholders, but we've continued to invest in the growth of Woolworths' business.

On average inventory days, we're up slightly at 33.8. A lot of that's been impacted – that little kick-up in average inventory days by increased indent, Cellarmasters and the investment in the Home Improvement inventory. If you take those one-offs out, or those impacts out, we were down about half a day from the normal retail businesses.

In terms of our balance sheet, inventory gearing kicked up a bit to some of those reasons we just talked about in terms of indent and home improvement, et cetera and in particular, Cellarmasters, which came in at the end of the year. Receivables also ticked up a bit because of Cellarmasters and some of the businesses we've bought under the Danks business, which had receivables as part of their business structure.

Fixed assets were up, primarily property, plant and equipment, purchases, development, net of disposals. Intangibles were up primarily due to Cellarmasters and borrowings are up because of the CapEx and property program that we're undertaking.
In terms of shareholder payouts, a great history there, 10 years and $10.3 billion returned to shareholders. So it's a very strong effort over those 10 years.

In terms of capital management, we had quite a bit of activity in relation to capital management. We've owed – in the 2010 year, returned $1 billion of capital to shareholders, excluding dividends of course. We raised just over $2 billion in the U.S. 144A market, and we raised $500 million in the Australian debt market. All those debt raisings were heavily over-subscribed and they all had to be scaled back, which meant that we got very good pricing on all those debt deals. So that was a very, very good effort for the year.

In terms of upcoming refinancing, we have notified the market we're going to repay our $600 million hybrid notes – the notice went out a little while ago. And we've got about $1.7 billion of bank facilities coming up and they – plans are in place to refinance those, and there won't be any issues with refinancing those maturities.

Return on funds employed, it's about 29%, slightly down on last year. If you look at the impact adjusting for the property development investment that we're making, you can see that, that return on funds employed has been relatively consistent over the last few years. Earnings per share, last slide, up 6.5%, a very good outcome. Thank you all. Back to Michael.
Thanks, Tom.

The next slide is one that – when it comes up. There it is. It has been one that we've shared with this group and the media over a number of years.
